reasoning: The critique targets one step in Sec. 3.3: the claim that bounded “universal value” views are practically linear because humanity’s marginal contribution is tiny relative to (possibly infinite) cosmic value. This is a supporting move for the essay’s broader “most plausible views are fussy” conclusion, but it is not the whole case (the essay also argues fussiness from moral-catastrophe fragility/multiplicativity, unbounded linear views, and bounded difference-making views). So centrality is moderate-low. The critique’s core point is fairly strong: the linearization depends on (i) a substantive cosmological premise and (ii) a particular evaluative domain/aggregation assumption (global impartial aggregation across the whole universe), and many moral frameworks instead restrict evaluation to the affectable region or are agent-/responsibility-relative, in which case the ‘tiny marginal’ premise fails and bounded concavity might matter. However, the essay itself already frames this as “the most natural” bounded view and then explores other bounded forms; plus even if the linearization fails, bounded views can still be fussy for other reasons the essay discusses. So it weakens that subargument but doesn’t overturn the main thesis. Most claims in the critique are plausible and largely accurate, though some parts are a bit overstated (e.g., that restricting to affectable region is “common” and that this alone makes easygoingness “far less narrow and specific” without engaging the essay’s other bounded-view fussiness arguments). Clear, focused, and with little extraneous material.
title: Bounded value functions remain non-linear when restricted to affectable regions
